description: Borrowed from Latin saturātus, perfect passive participle of saturāre (“to fill full”), from satur (“full”).

adjectives.description: saturate (comparative more saturate, superlative most saturate)

entries.meaning: (chemistry) Something saturated, especially a saturated fat.

verbs.description: saturate (third-person singular simple present saturates, present participle saturating, simple past and past participle saturated)

entries.meaning: To cause to become completely impregnated, or soaked (especially with a liquid).
examples: Suppose, on the contrary, that a piece of charcoal saturated with hydrogen gas is put into a receiver filled with carbonic acid gas,  […]
Modern television is saturated with violence.

entries.meaning: To satisfy the affinity of; to cause a substance to become inert by chemical combination with all that it can hold.
examples: One can saturate phosphorus with chlorine.

entries.meaning: (optics) To render pure, or of a colour free from white light.
